awd_titl_txt: Creating Adoptable Computing Education Integrated into Social Studies Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to provide more students computing education by integrating programming activities into social studies classes and to use the computing to enhance students’ data literacy. Today, few students see computer science in high schools. Even in states with 40% or more of high schools offering a computer science class, less than 5% of students take that opportunity. Every high school student takes history. This project is developing an on-line education research curriculum for data literacy and data visualization tools and providing on-going support to teachers. This project supports students computationally to build data visualizations in history classes, with programming explicitly. This project also tackles the challenge of supporting social studies teachers to adopt the data literacy curriculum and the integrated computing education activities. Over a three-year period, the project is tracking teachers from a pre-service teacher data literacy course, into their field experience, and on into their in-service placement. Over three years, the project will describe the factors that influence adoption and non-adoption. This project is unique in its focus on developing curriculum and technology purpose-built for social studies with teacher involvement to improve adoption. The potential of the project is both to provide computing education to a larger number and more diverse range of students and to provide data literacy in a history context.

The project draws on three theoretical frameworks. The Technology Adoption Model suggests that teachers will adopt technology that has high perceived usefulness and high perceived usability. Design-based research informs what data to collect and how to analyze it when conducting a multi-year iterative study. Participatory design informs how to involve teachers in the design process so that the curriculum and technology meets teachers’ perceptions of usefulness and usability. The project takes an iterative approach to developing an on-line education research curriculum for data literacy and data visualization tools and also in the designed support for teachers. The goal of the support to teachers (pre-service and in-service) is both to develop their knowledge and to inform the design of the curriculum and technology so that it can be adapted to increase adoption. This project is supported by the CS for All program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite the growing importance of computing education in today's society, less than 10% of US high school students take a computer science (CS) class. Our project aimed to expand computing education opportunities to more students by integrating computing education into social studies classes, by focusing on data literacy. All 50 states require social studies classes to include data literacy, which includes creating, reading, understanding, and using data visualizations. CS standards include objectives around working with data, visualizing data, and using data representations in making arguments. Our project was aimed at finding ways to integrate data literacy into social studies classes by making it more easily adoptable.

Project Overview:

Over the four-year duration of this grant, we explored ways to create data literacy tools and practices that are easily adoptable by social studies teachers. We worked closely with practicing and pre-service social studies teachers through participatory design. This collaborative approach helped us understand the unique needs of social studies teachers and led to the creation of new tools for data visualizations. We have studied teachers in the classroom. In one study, we followed practicing history teachers over two years to see when and how they adopted data literacy in their classes. In our largest and longest study, we followed a set of new social studies teachers, from their pre-service classes on using data literacy in social studies classes into their first year as practicing teachers.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit:

Designing Effective Tools:

We have learned the importance of designing for and with social studies teachers if we want to create tools that they find acceptable for their classes. Social studies teachers have different needs for data visualization than STEM teachers. For example, social studies teachers need to know where the data came from, because they want to understand possible bias in the data. We found that history teachers want to see pairs of visualizations so that they can easily compare and contrast findings. Even great visualization tools like CODAP make it difficult to create two contrasting visualizations. We ended up building multiple tools, and social studies teachers told us that the tools were usable and adoptable.

Adoption Challenges:

But getting social studies teachers to adopt data literacy in their classrooms is about more than tools. We studied three practicing history teachers over two years. These teachers each participated in multiple professional learning opportunities. They tried out several data visualization tools. What actually got them to teach about data literacy in their classrooms included factors like:

  • Finding time to try their lessons, more than once. Several teachers were dissatisfied with their first attempt.
  • Finding a good place in their curriculum. Data visualization isn’t great for teaching everything, and teachers wanted to find a good fit with a particular unit.
  • Finding the right tools. Teachers tried several things before they found one that worked for their students, their classroom context, and their learning goals.

We are just finishing our longitudinal study of social studies teachers from pre-service into practice. In general, few of our participants actually taught data literacy in their classes. While in the pre-service classroom, our participants were engaged and eager to teach data literacy. But once they got into the classroom, they found it to be harder than they expected. As one teacher put it, “Once you’re teaching, you’re consumed with so much!” They didn’t get feedback on their teaching, especially on a new topic like data literacy, so their confidence suffered.

Broader Impacts:

Our study highlights the broader impact of integrating computing education into non-CS subjects like social studies:

  • Enhanced Teacher Engagement: Our participatory design approach not only resulted in effective tools but also led to greater teacher engagement and ownership of the process.
  • Curriculum Development: Insights from our studies can inform the development of future curricula that incorporate data literacy into social studies, potentially reaching a broader student population.

Our research with pre-service teachers showed that initial enthusiasm did not always translate into classroom practice. Many new teachers found it challenging to implement data literacy lessons due to various demands and lack of feedback on this new topic.

Conclusion:

We conclude this project confident in the importance of incorporating data literacy in social studies education. Our tools and pre-service teacher training are promising steps toward this goal. However, we recognize that additional support and refined strategies are necessary to overcome the challenges faced by teachers in adopting these practices. This project contributes valuable insights and tools that can serve as a foundation for future efforts to make computing education more accessible to a broader range of students.
